CALOGERO:
It's 3 AM in the Bronx, New York. I'm on the corner of 187th and Belmont Avenue. This was my neighborhood. I can still hear a million voices in my head. Hear a million stories.

CALOGERO:
♫ This is a bronx tale.And it's my story...the world I lived in,the people I knew.

CALOGERO:
♫ It's just a BRONX TALEAND, LIKE THEY ALL DO,It starts right hereon belmont avenue.

CALOGERO:
My name is Calogero Lorenzo Alfredo Romano Anello.

CALOGERO:
This is my building. And that's my stoop. My stoop. I grew up right over a bar called the Chez Bippy.

CALOGERO:
It's where all the wise guys hung out. And on warm summer nights all through the neighborhood

CALOGERO:
And then there was Sonny. He was the number one man in the neighborhood. Sonny had five fingers. But he only used three.

CALOGERO:
All day and all night, he'd be right here on the corner. He would stand here nodding his head to all the old ladies going by with their shopping,

CALOGERO:
and they treated him like a god. And in my neighborhood, he was a god.

CALOGERO:
I couldn't take my eyes off of him.

CALOGERO:
But he never ever looked at me. Never. Until one day...I was 9 years old.
(Car tires screech to a stop and crash)

GUY WITH BAT:
Get back here! You got a problem with me?
CARMINE:
Yeah I got a problem.

GUY WITH BAT:
Oh yeah?
(Gunshot)
(Second gunshot)

TONY TEN TO TWO:
C’mon

CALOGERO:
♫ THIS IS A BRONX TALE.AND IT'S MY STORY.

CALOGERO:
♫ THE ONE THAT SHATTERED THE WORLD THAT I KNEW.

CALOGERO:
♫ HERE'S HOW IT HAPPENED, AND ALL OF IT'S TRUE.

CALOGERO:
♫ IT STARTS RIGHT HERE,ON BELMONT AVENUE.

Calogero!
ROSINA:
Are you alright? Are you alright?

YOUNG CALOGERO:
I'm okay Mommy.
ROSINA:
Thank God.

YOUNG CALOGERO:
Daddy, they were fighting over a parking space. Sonny shot him. Why? It was just a parking space. Why?

LORENZO:
It wasn't the parking space, son. Who knows why. Maybe they just met at the wrong time in their lives. Come on, let's get up stairs.

ROSINA:
I don't want himinvolved in this.

Come here kid. You think you can point out the guy who pulled the trigger?

YOUNG CALOGERO:
Sure.

CALOGERO:
Lined up in front of my building were five guys. And they were Sonny's crew. And I knew every one of them.

CALOGERO:
In my neighborhood the lowest thing anyone could be is a rat. And I wasn't a rat.

CALOGERO:
The day after the killing my father insisted that I ride the bus with him. I used to love to ride the bus with my dad.

CALOGERO:
I would sit right behind him and he would listen to jazz on a little transistor radio. Everyone loved him.

CALOGERO:
His uniform was always so neat and clean and his top button was always closed even if it was ninety nine degrees.

CALOGERO:
My dad never wanted to look sloppy. I was so proud of him. Last stop:

LORENZO:
City Island.

LORENZO:
How you feeling Calogero?
YOUNG CALOGERO:
I’m okay.

LORENZO:
You were quiet on the bus.
YOUNG CALOGERO:
Just thinking.

LORENZO:
About what happened yesterday?

YOUNG CALOGERO:
I thought I did a good thing but now I'm not so sure Dad.

LORENZO:
You did a good thing for a bad man, son. What you did was right. Okay?

YOUNG CALOGERO:
Thanks Dad.

LORENZO:
Alright! Who's the greatest ballplayer that ever lived?
YOUNG CALOGERO:
Mickey Mantle!

LORENZO:
No way. Joe DiMaggio. The Yankee Clipper. And do you know why he was so great?

YOUNG CALOGERO:
Because he was Italian?

LORENZO:
That's part of it. It's because he had talent and he used it.
YOUNG CALOGERO:
Do I have talent?

LORENZO:
Of course you do.
YOUNG CALOGERO:
Just like Joe D.

LORENZO:
Yeah, just like Joe D.

CALOGERO:

CALOGERO:

CALOGERO:
So just for spite, Rudy would never utter a spoken word. He would only sing it.

FRANKIE COFFEECAKE:

CALOGERO:
Frankie Coffee Cake.(2 Camera Flash Sounds)

EDDIE MUSH:

CALOGERO:
That's Eddie Mush. (2 Camera Flash Sounds)

CALOGERO:
Now Eddie Mush was a degenerate gambler. He was also the biggest loser in the whole world.

CALOGERO:
He was such a loser he would go to the racetrack and the teller would give him his tickets already ripped up.

JOJO THE WHALE:
(He laughs)
CALOGERO:
JoJo the Whale.(2 Camera Flash Sounds)

CALOGERO:
Five foot eight. 400 pounds. He was so fat, legend has it his shadow once killed a dog.

CALOGERO:
And then there was Sonny's bodyguard, Tony Ten to Two.(2 Camera Flash Sounds)

CALOGERO:
They called him Ten to Two because his feet always pointed like the clock, ten to two. (Audience Laughter)

CALOGERO:
One time he got shot in the leg and they called him twenty after. But the best times of all were the crap games.

CALOGERO:
All the big wise guys from all over the neighborhood would come by. Tammy Russo, Paulie Z, Billy BaBa.

CALOGERO:
All of them would stand there acting like who was the toughest, who was the strongest, who had the biggest reputation.

CALOGERO:
And I would watch thousands of dollars change hands back and forth.
